title: 115_hr2213
content: The Act titled "Anti-Border Corruption Reauthorization Act of 2017" provides hiring flexibility. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 (Public Law 111-376; 6 U.S.C. 221) allows the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection to waive certain requirements for law enforcement officers employed by State or local agencies with at least 3 years of service and statutory powers for arrest or apprehension. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 allows the waiver of requirements for law enforcement officers with at least 3 years of service and the power of arrest or apprehension. The officer must not be under investigation, engaged in criminal activity, resigned under investigation, or dismissed from a law enforcement position. Additionally, they must have completed a polygraph examination within the past 10 years. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 allows for a waiver of requirements for law enforcement officers with a minimum of 3 years of service, the authority to make arrests, and a clean disciplinary record. They must also hold a current Tier 4 or Tier 5 background investigation. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 allows for a waiver of requirements for individuals with military service of at least 3 years, specific security clearances, background investigations, honorable discharge, and no criminal or serious military offenses under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 allows waivers for individuals meeting specific military service and clearance criteria, but waivers must not be granted for clearance under certain circumstances. The authority to issue waivers will end 5 years after the enactment of the Anti-Border Corruption Reauthorization Act of 2017. SEC. 4 of the Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 is amended to grant supplemental commissioner authority. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 grants supplemental commissioner authority regarding waivers for individuals receiving background investigation waivers under subsection (b) of section 3. This includes non-exemption from hiring requirements, subjecting individuals to a Tier 5 background investigation if they hold a current Tier 4 investigation, and authorizing the administration of polygraph examinations by the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 grants the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection authority to administer polygraph examinations for employment suitability determinations. Section 5 of the Act focuses on reporting requirements. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 mandates the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection to provide annual reports to congressional committees on waivers requested, granted, and denied for employment applications, including polygraph examination results. The Anti-Border Corruption Act of 2010 now includes definitions for key terms such as 'law enforcement officer,' 'veteran,' 'serious military or civil offense,' and 'Tier 4' and 'Tier 5.' These definitions align with specific sections of the United States Code and military regulations.
